document.docAuthor: López-Orozco, Carlos Mario, Carpio-Díaz, Yesenia M., Borja-Arrieta, Ricardo, Navas-S, Gabriel R., Campos-Filho, Ivanklin Soares, Taiti, Stefano, Mateos, Mariana, Olazaran, Alexandra, Caballero, Isabel C., Jotty, Karick, Gómez-Estrada, Harold & Hurtado, Luis A.
document.docTitle: Tylos negroi Lopez-Orozco, Carpio-Diaz & Campos-Filho 2022, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A glimpse into a remarkable unknown diversity of oniscideans along the Caribbean coasts revealed on a tiny island

subSubSection.paragraph: The new species is named after Mr Hernando Gómez Molina, also known as Mr Negro, for his efforts to conserve the biodiversity of the Rosario Islands.

materialsCitation.collectorName: C. M. Lopez-Orozco & R. Borja-Arrieta & Y. M. Carpio- Diaz

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype
COLOMBIA –
Bolívar , Cartagena de Indias , Islas del Rosario , Isla Grande
• ♂ ; Playa Libre ; 10°10′52.3″ N , 75°43′54.8″ W ;
5 Oct. 2017
; C.M. López-Orozco , R. Borja-Arrieta and Y.M. Carpio- Díaz leg.; CUDC-CRU 127 .

MEASUREMENTS. Maximum body length: male 10 mm ; female 8.1 mm .
BODY. Colour yellowish with many irregular dark spots ( Fig. 2B ). Body outline as in Fig. 3A . Endoantennal conglobation. Dorsum covered with lanceolate scale-setae ( Fig. 3B ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 3.
Tylos negroi López-Orozco, Carpio-Díaz & Campos-Filho
sp. nov. , paratype, ♂ (CDUC- CRU 128). A . Habitus, lateral view. B . Dorsal scale-seta. C . Cephalon, frontal view. D . Cephalon, dorsal view. E . Epimera of pereonites 1–3, ventral view. F . Pleonites 4, 5 and telson, dorsal view. G . Pleon, ventral view. H . Antennula.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Presently, the genus
Tylos
has a worldwide distribution and comprises 21 coastal species ( Schmalfuss & Vergara 2000 ; Schmalfuss 2003 ). In Colombia , only
T . niveus Budde-Lund, 1885
was recorded from the Caribbean region (
Carpio-Díaz et al. 2016
).
Tylos negroi
sp. nov. can be distinguished from all species of the genus by the shape of the ventral phylacomera 5. Moreover, it differs from
T. niveus
in the pereonite 1 epimeron having the inner lobe of the schisma surpassing the outer lobe (vs inner lobe not surpassing outer lobe) and the pereopod 7 propodus being inflated (vs not inflated).
Presently known only from Isla Grande, Cartagena de Indias, Colombia .
